text:
Windows does have rudimentary scripting - DOS batch files.

You won't need nearly so memory if you use a DOS batch file to launch JMeter,
particularly if you use the -n (non-GUI) option.

Also check out the FAQ for information on parameterising test plans:

http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-jmeter/JMeterFAQ

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
I've now looked at the test plan, and I see you have parameterised it - sorry, I
should have looked at that earlier. I think you could pass in the list.dat file
as a parameter using a nested ${__P()} function call, which would save having to
copy the data file.

Since you have already written a java class to create the jmeter command lines,
you could use this to create a DOS batch file instead of using exec() to run it.

The BAT file should look someting like:

cd /D PATH
java -jar ApacheJMeter.jar -l [alpha|rand]_[nom|...].jtl .....
java -jar ApacheJMeter.jar -l [alpha|rand]_[nom|...].jtl .....
java -jar ApacheJMeter.jar -l [alpha|rand]_[nom|...].jtl .....
...
java -jar ApacheJMeter.jar -l [alpha|rand]_[nom|...].jtl .....

All of this could be done directly using DOS batch commands, but nested loops
can get a bit tricky.
